respStmt.resp: XML encoding, hyperlinking and textual cleanup

availability.p: This text may be freely distributed, subject to the following restrictions:

list.item: You credit Perseus, as follows, whenever you use the document: Text provided by Perseus Digital Library, with funding from The U.S. Department of Education and The Max Planck Society.
You leave this availability statement intact.
You offer Perseus any modifications you make.

notesStmt.note: Initial XML cleanup by Alpheios Technical Services, LLC.
Major XML restructuring and text-correction by Winfried H. Leclaire of quranic-research.net
Additional proofreading by Naveed Ul Islam of lanelexicon.com

list.item: First issue published by Perseus Digital Library on 07th April 2011

entry.sense: hu: the vowel of this pron. is sometimes, in a case of pause, transferred to the preceding letter: and this is always done in modern Arabic.
ho subjoined in hun-aho, and the like: see OaboyaDu.

The haA, termed tanobiyhN, is said by some to be used as an inceptive, without any meaning but inception. (See cA.) See kalimapu tanobiyhK in art. nbh: and see an ex. voce taA. When followed by a pronoun, as hw, &c., it is best rendered Lo.
h of pausation: see remarks on a verse cited voce HiynN.
bihaA, in HaTaOa bihaA, and many phrases syn. therewith, is app. for biQsotihi. See HaTaOa.
haMCa and haMCi: see art. hwO.

Q. Q. 3. Aihobay-axa; (Ḳ;) and Aihobay-axato, aor. tahobay-ixu; inf. n. Uihobiy-aAxN; (TA;) He, (Ḳ,) and she, (TA,) walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (Ḳ, TA.)
habay-axN, of the measure faEay-alN, (Ṣ,) A boy, or young man: and habay-axapN a girl, or damsel: both in the dial. of Himyer. (L.)

Also, the former, A soft boy, or young man: (Ḳ:) or the former and latter, respectively, a soft, thin-skinned, and plump, boy or young man, (Ṣ,) and girl or damsel: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a plump and goodly young man, and woman: (L:) or the latter, a tall and great woman: (JK:) [and hence, app., applied as an epithet, in the sense of long and large, to a woman's train, in the following verse, quoted by Az,]
jar-ato Ealayohi Alr-iyHu cayolFA OanobaxaA
jar-a AlEaruwsi cayolahaA Qlohabay-axaA . (L.) [The wind dragged over it a train of dusky colour, and abounding with dust, like as the bride drags her long and large train.]
Also, the latter, A damsel suckling, or that suckles. (M, Ḳ.)
Also, the former, A stupid, and flabby, or flaccid, man. (Ḳ.)
Also, a man in whom is no good. (Ḳ.)
Also, A great valley. (Ḳ)
And A large river. (Ḳ.)
hubaEN, applied to a young camel: a young camel brought forth in the end of the breedingtime. (Ḳ, voce rubaEN, q. v.) See bulaEN.
1. habilato, inf. n. habalN: see Eamila.
8. Aihotabala: see 5 in art. Hfw.
I. q. taHay-ana. (TA.)
hayobaliI-N A Christian monk: see OabiylN.
mahobilN The place of gestation: see a verse cited voce maHobalN.
1. habAa Alr-amaAdu, (JK, TA,) aor. yahobuw, (TA,) The ashes became mixed with dust, and extinguished: (JK, TA:) and habAa Aljamoru. (M, art. rmd.)
hubapN: see OahobapN.
habowapN Dust rising, or spreading, in the sky like smoke. (JK.)
habaMCN The motes that are seen in the rays of the sun: (TA:) see an ex. voce guvaMCN.
1. htk He rent open. (Ḳ, Ṣ.)
htk Qll-eh sitorahu God dishonour him: see sitorN.
hat-aAkN One who rends frequently tents and the like: see baAbN.
5. tahaj-aEa He slept. (1001 Nights, ii. 321.)
hajoEapN † The setting of a star. (Ṣgh in TA, art. XrT.) See XaraTN.
A light sleep in the first part of the night. (Ṣ.)
hawojalN, of a ship or boat, is smaller than the Oanojar. (O, TA, voce maEaAbiyru.)
See De Sacy, Chrest. Arab., ii. 359.
hajuwlN A fornicatress, or an adulteress: pl. hajaAYilu. (JK.)

1. hajamu Ealayohi He came upon him suddenly, or at unawares, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or came in to him without permission, (Ḳ,) or without asking permission: (Mgh:) he invaded, assaulted, assailed, attacked, attempted, or ventured upon, him or it: he pounced upon him or it.
hajomapN, or, accord. to Ḳz, haziyEN, The third of the five divisions of the night. (TA.) See xudorapN, and yaEofuwrN.
As applied to camels, see EaAYiDN and ziyAadapN.
1. nakaHa fiI baniI fulAanK wahaj-ana OawolaAdahumo [He married among the sons of such a one, and made their children to be base-born, or ignoble]. (TA in art. bgl.)
hujonapN [Meanness of race, in a horse]. (Ḳ, voce UiEorAabN.)
hajiynN One whose father is free, or an Arab, and whose mother is a slave. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

A horse [half-blooded] got by a stallion of generous race out of a mare not of such race: (Ṣ:) or got by an Arabian stallion out of a mare not of Arabian birth: (Mṣb:) or not of generous birth; a jade. (Ḳ.)
haAjinN A girl not arrived at puberty, or a beast not yet fit to be covered: see an ex. voce jal-a.
1. hajaAhu He censured, dispraised, reviled, or satirized him, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in verse. (Mṣb, Ḳ)
maA hajawotu minohu XayoYFA: see 1 in art. Hjw.
3. haAjaAhu, inf. n. muhaAjaApN, He contended with him in satirizing. See 4 in art. fHm.
Oumojuw-apN Dispraise, is like OusobuwbapN, contr. of OumoduwHapN.
10. Aisotahodafa He became a hadaf, or butt. (Ḥar, p. 65.) See ratiymapN.
hadafN A high or lofty building: see SadafN.
1. hadala He uttered a cry: see hadara, in two places.
5. tahad-ala It hung down; [it dangled;] said of a branch of a tree, (Ṣ, TA,) and of fruit; it hung loosely; said of the former. (TA.)
miXofarN Oahodalu [A camel's lip] flaccid, or pendulous. (Ḳ, TA.)

1. hadama He threw down, or pulled down, a building; (Mṣb;) pulled it to pieces; demolished it; destroyed it: (Ḳ:) [the last two explanations are the most correct, as is shown by the phrase] naqaDa AlbinaMCa mino Eayori hadomi [He took to pieces the building without demolishing, or destroying]: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,* in art. qwD:) he ruined [a building, &c.]; reduced [it] to ruin. (Ḥam, p. 31.)
6. tahaAdamati AlHiyTaAnu [The walls fell to ruin by degrees]. (Ṣ, in art. dEw.)
7. Ainohadama It became thrown down, pulled down, pulled to pieces, demolished, or destroyed: and it fell in ruins, or to pieces; or became a ruin.
Ainohadama AlHaAYiTu mino makaAnihi mino gayori hadomN [The wall fell in ruins, or to pieces, from its place, without being pulled to pieces]. (Lth, in TA, art. qyD.)
Ald-amu Ald-amu waAlhadomu Alhadomu or waAlhadama Alhadama: see damN in art. dmw or dmI.
hadamN Earth that is dug from a pit or well: see HafarN.
hidamolapN Food and drink: see fiToHalN.
hudonapN EalaI daxonK An illusory truce: see duxaAnN.
1. hadaAhu He directed him, or guided him, to the way; (Ḳ,* TA;) directed him aright; or caused him to take, or follow, a right way or course or direction. (Ḳ, TA.) See 8.
hadaI AlEaruwsa He sent [or conducted] the bride (MA, KL) to her husband, (MA,) or to the house of her husband: (KL;) i. q. zaf-ahaA, (Ḳ in art. zf,) and so OahodaAhaA↓. (Mṣb in that art.)
yahodiI meaning yuWad-iI: see an ex. in a verse cited voce TabaEN.
4. OahodaIa see 1.
6. tahaAdanaA They (two parties who had been at war) made a truce, each with the other. (T, art. nbc.)

sense.hi: He went a right way: went aright.

entry.sense: laA yahotadiI UilaI jihapK He cannot go aright: or knows not the way that he would pursue; or knows not in what direction to go: sometimes said of a drunken man.
laA yahotadiI liOamorihi means He does not, or cannot, find the way to accomplish, or perform, his affair.
AihotadaI He found, (MA,) or took (KL,) the right way or road. (MA, KL.)

daAhiyapu lAa yuhotadaI lahaA, by which daAhiyapu Algabari is expl. in the Ṣ and O, means laA yuhotadaI ll-an-ajaMCi minohaA, by which the same phrase is expl. in the JK: or it may be well rendered A calamity in relation to which one knows not the right course to pursue.
AihotadaI also signifies He continued to be rightly directed, or to follow a right dirertion: and he sought to be rightly directed, or to follow a right direction. (TA.)
Aihad-aI and Aihid-iI, for AihotadaI; like AiEac-ara and AiEic-ira, for AiEotacara.

hom.sense: hadoIN A way, course, method, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or proceeding, or the like; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also hidoyapN↓ and hadoyapN↓: (Ḳ:) or to the second and third: and the first is pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of the last: (Ṣ:) and a god way,, &c.: and calm, or placid, deportment; or calmness, or placidity, of deportment: (TA:) see also dalN.

entry.sense: huwa EalaI hudFI He is following, or he follows, a right direction.
AlhudaI The Ḳur-án. (Bḍ, Jel in lxxii. 13, &c.)
hidoyapN and hadoyapN: see hadoyN.
hadiy-apN [n. un. of hadiI-N] A present; i. e. a thing sent to another in token of courtesy or honour: (Mṣb;) such as is termed TariyfN and laTafN. (JK.)

hadoIN↓ and hadiI-N [coll. gen. ns.] What one brings as an offering to Mekkeh, (Ḳ,) or to the Kaabeh, (Beyd, v. 2,) or to the Haram, (Ṣ, Mgh,) consisting of camels (Lth, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) or other beasts, (Lth,) namely kine or sheep or goats, (Mgh,) to be sacrificed, (TA,) and of goods or commodities: (Lth:) n. un. with p {hadiy-apN}. (Ṣ, &c.)
Also, Camels, absolutely. (TA.)
hadiI-N also One who is entitled to respect, or honour, or protection: so in a verse cited voce AisotabaMCa. (ISk in T in art. bwO.)
haAdK: see an ex. of its pl. hawaAdiI meaning Necks of horses, voce taAlK.
haAdiyapN The fore part of the neck of a horse. (Ḳ in art. slf.)
Oaxaca haAdiIa Alr-aHaI fajaEala yudiyruhaA [He took the handle of the mill, and begun to turn it]. (Ḳ, art. xbz.)
OahodaI mino duEayomiySi Alr-amoli More expert,, &c.: see art. dEmS.

AlmahodiI-u, meaning The directed by God to the truth, is a proper name, and the name of him of whose coming at the end of time the happy tidings have been announced. (TA.) [It is always so pronounced by the Arabs in the present day: not AlmuhodiI.]
1. hac-a bisaloHihi He ejected his excrement. (TA, art. tr.)
1. hacaI He talked nonsense; he raved, or talked irrationally, foolishly, or deliriously; (JK, Ḳ;) by reason of disease or some other cause. (Ḳ.)
hacaIbihi He talked irrationally,, &c., with him. (TA.)
And He mentioned him, or it, in his irrational,, &c., talk. (TA.)
3. gaEada yuhaAciI OaSoHaAbahu [He sat talking irrationally,, &c., with his companions]. (TA.)
samiEotuhumo yatahaAcuwna [I heard them talking together irrationally,, &c.] (TA.)
XaraAbN haAcK ‡ [Beverage causing delirious, or irrational, talk.] (TA.)

1. har-a, inf. n. hir-N, He drove sheep or goats: (IAạr, in Ṣ, Ḳ, voce bir:)
or he called them. (Yoo, in TA, ibid.)
hirojaAlN, pl. haraAjyl, A tall, long-bodied, or bulky, she-camel: (TA:) see hirojaAb.
haraAHa: see OaraAHa.
harAasN A certain thorny or prickly tree, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) the thorns or prickles of which are like the Hasak, (TA,) and its fruit is like the nabiq: n. un. with p {harAasapN}. (Ḳ, TA.) See quTobN.
hiroXaf-apN A piece of rag with which water is dried up from the ground. (TA, art. jf.)
See hiroXab-apN.
hiroTaAlN A large long-bodied man. (Az, in TA, voce hirodab-apN.)
1. hariqo EalaI xamorika [Pour water upon thy wine; i. e.,] quiet thine anger. (T.) See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 875; also the same, ii. 877.
hariqo Ean-aA mino ruwbapi All-ayoli: see ruwbapN.
4. Oahoriqo Eanoka mina AlZ-ahiyrapi i. q. Oaborido, q. v. (IAạr, in TA, art. fyH.) See 4 in art. rwq.
haraAqahu and OahorAaqahu and haraqahu↓, aor. _a {yahoraqu}, inf. n. haroqN, He poured it out, or forth: see 4 in art. rwq.

hariyquwA Eanokumo Oaw-ala All-ayoli, (in the Ḳ, erroneously, Ealayokumo,) Alight ye in the first of the night: (TA:) or disburden yourselves (OanoziluwA Enkm): or relieve, or rest, yourselves; which seems to be generally meant by hryqwA Enkm.
hiraAqapN and UihoraAfapN The seminal fluid of a man: see UiraAqapN, in art. rwq.

Q. Q. 1. harowala He walked quickly: (Mṣb:) [he went a kind of trotting pace between a walk and a run; see ramala;] harowalapN is not so quick as xababN [an amble]; (Mṣb;) and is between maXoIN [a walk] and EadowN [a run]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) it is a kind of EadowN: (Ṣ:) or quicker than EanaqN: or a quick walk. (Ḳ.)
1. harima He became extremely aged; (Ḳ;) old and infirm; (Mṣb;) decrepit; or a weak old man.
harimN The mind: see 6 in art. rq.
Alkur-u AlhaAruwniI-u: see kur-N.

hrnSAnp The hrnSAnp, (Ḳ,) i. e. hironiSaAnap, (TA,) or hirinoSaAnap, (so in the CK, and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,) with kesr, (Ḳ,) and the r quiescent, and with kesr to the n, (TA,) is A certain worm, (Ḳ,) accord. to IAạr; said by others to be (TA) what is called the surofap [which is very variously described]. (Ḳ, TA.) See duxolulN.
huroIN A granary: see niborN.
hazaw-arN A strong boy or young man: and a weak old man: as also Hazaw-arN: pl. hazAawirapN. (Abu-t-Teiyib, in TA, art. Hzr.)
haziyEN: see hajomapN.

1. hazolN is contr. of jid-N. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ.) You say, hazala, aor. _i {yahozilu}, inf. n. hazolN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and hazila, aor. _a {yahozalu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) and haAzala↓; (Ḳ;) He jested, or joked; (Mṣb;) or was not serious, or in earnest; (TA;) fiI kalAamihi in his speech; (Mṣb, TA;) and fiI AlOamori in the affair. (TA.)
3. haAzala He jested, or joked. (Ḳ.) See 1.
huzAalN Leanness, meagreness, emaciation: contr. of fatness. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
hazolaI, pl. of haziylN Lean, meagre, emaciated. (Ḳ, voce xaXabN.)
mahozuwlN: see two exs. in a verse cited voce EiroDN.
7. Ainohazama It (an army) was routed, discomfited, defeated, or put to flight. (Ḳ, &c.) See HaASa, in art. HyS; and AinoHaAza, in art. Hwz; from both of which it is distinguished.
hazomapN The [purring, or] sound of the throat of a cat. (TA.)
The pit between the two collar-bones. (TA, art. trb.)

[The pit above a horse's eye.] (Ḳ, voce waqobN.) See also xunoEubapN, and qalotapN: and see EuqomN, where it seems to mean a stricture: it generally and properly signifies a depression, or dint: or a pit, or small hollow, resembling a dint: see also gayobN.
mahozuwmu AlS-adori Depressed of breast, i. e., apparently, illiberal, niggardly: see HawoDN.
1. haXamahu He crushed it.
2. haX-amahu, inf. n. tahoXiymN, He broke it [much, or so crushed it]; (TA;) namely, a dry thing, and anything hollow, such as the head, and the like. (TA in art. Xdx.)
5. tahaX-ama It (a plant, or herbage,) became haXiym, i. e. dry, and broken in pieces.
haXiymN A plant that is dry, and breaks, or is broken, in pieces. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
haAXimapN A wound in the head which breaks the bone: see Xaj-apN.
Alkur-u AlhaAXimiI-u: see kur-N.
1. hDamahu and AihotaDamahu: see taxaw-afahu.
haDama lahu mino maAlihi: see xaDama.
5. tahaD-ama see 7.
7. AinohaDama It (a thing) melted, or dissolved, after being congealed. (JK.)
AinohaDamati Alv-amarapu, and tahaD-amat↓, The fruit broke; or became broken, or crushed; syn. taXad-axato; (TA;) and became mellow, so as to be easy of digestion. See also bawoEN
AinohaDama, said of food, (MA), It was, or became, digestible, or easy of digestion. (MA, KL.)
AinohDaAmN of the zawor [app. Depression]. (Ḳ in art. jnf. [There coupled with duxuwlN.]) See also SaqalN.
8. UihotaDama see 1.
AihotaDama AlX-ajaza mino OaEalAahu (Ḳ voce XaEaba) He cropped the tops of the shrubs: see XaEaba.
haDamN Contraction of the sides, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and lankness of the belly, and smallness of the flank: (Ḳ:) in a horse it is a fault. (Ṣ.)
haDuwmN: see haADuwmN.
haADuwmN Any medicine [or other thing (see HaATuwmN)] that is a digestive of food; as also haDuwmN↓; (Ḳ;) i. q. jawaAriXN. (Ṣ.)
1. haTala It (water) poured: see its inf. n. voce sakobN.
hif-N Certain small fish, which are dried: see sumayokaMCu.
1. hfA, said of the heart, It fluttered, or palpitated; and, as Z says, was flurried by reason of grief, or of beating. (TA.) See 1, in art. fhw.
hafowapN A slip, lapse, fault, or fall into wrongdoing; pl. hafawaAtN. (TA.)
qarabN haqohaAqN: see HaqoHaAqN.
hiqowar-N A large, long-bodied man. (Az, in TA, voce hirodab-apN.)

AlhaqoEapu Three small stars [λ, φ 1, and φ 2, of Orion,] forming the points of a triangle, in the head of AljuwozAaCu The 5th Mansion of the Moon. (El-Ḳazweenee.) [This is accord. to those who make nawoCN to signify the “auroral setting:” accord. to those who make it to signify the “auroral rising,” these stars compose AlhanoEapu, q. v.; and AlhafoEapu seems to consist of ο 1 and ο 2 of Orion.]
1. hak-a: see sak-a.
haAk-N: see faAk-N.
hak-aAkN: see fak-aAkN.
4. OaholalonaA hilaAla Xahori kacaA: see salaxa.
See also a verse cited voce OafovaOa.
See musotahal-N.
halo may be originally halow or haloI or hal-: (Akh, in Ṣ, voce bl:) see balo.
halo followed by UilaI: see the latter.
HaI- hala: see HI.
hal-aA: see HaD-apN and Eano, latter part, and lawolaA, and Oal-aA.
hal-apN: see bal-apN.
AlhilAalu The new moon; or the moon when it is termed hilAal: it may be explained as meaning, generally, the moon when near the sun, or moon a little after or before the change.
See samaA.
musotahal-u AlX-ahori The first night of the lunar month. (Mṣb.)
yawomN hil-awofN: see OaHaS-u.

1. halaka, inf. n. halaAkN, &c., (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) He, or it, perished, came to nought, came to an end, passed away, was not, was no more, or became non-existent or annihilated: (KL, PṢ in explanation of halAakN, &c.:) or fell: or became in a bad, or corrupt, state; became corrupted, vitiated, marred, or spoiled: or went away, no one knew whither: (Mgh in explanation of halAakN:) he died. (Ḳ.)
halakato OaroDuhu His land had its herbage dried up by drought: see jariba.
2. waAdiI tuhul-ika I. q. tuDul-il
4. Oaholakahu He destroyed, made an end of, or caused to perish or come to an end, made away, did away with, or brought to nought, him, or it; took away his life.
6. tahaAlaka gam-FA [app. He perished gradually by reason of grief.] (A, art. sws: see 1 in that art.)
tahaAlaka Ealayohi He was vehemently eager for it. (TA.)
tahaAlakato said of a she-camel, i. q. EaXiqato [She vehemently desired the stallion]. (AA, TA in art. EXq.)
8. Uihotalaka see 6.
10. Aisotaholaka properly signifies He sought, or courted, destruction; like AisotamaAta: see musotamiyta: and see an ex. voce XaroXarapN.
Aisotaholaka fiI kacaA He (a man) distressed, troubled, or fatigued, himself in, or respecting, such a thing. (TA.) See also 6.
halakapN The drying up of the plants, or herbage. (AḤn, TA.) See halAakN.
halAakN [Perdition; destruction; a state of perdition or destruction: a lost state;] death. (Ḳ.)
halAakN and halakapN↓ are syn. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Airotabaka fiI AinohalakaAti He stuck fast in cases of perdition: see art. rbk.
haAlikN Dead; or dying. (Bḍ, Jel in xii. 85)
haAlikN sometimes means Subject to perish; as in the Ḳur, xxviii. last verse.
maholukN: see OaluwkN.
maholikN Death: see a verse cited voce sahuwN.
maholakapN A cause of perdition, or of death. (TA in art. bxl.)

‡ A place of perdition or death: and a desert: (KL:) or a [desert, or such as is termed] mafaAzap; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) because persons perish therein; (Z, TA;) or because it urges [or leads] to perdition. (TA.) See jaAd-apN.
huwa musotaholikN UilaI kacaA i. q. musotamiytN [q. v.]. (TA, art. mwt, from the A.)
musotaholiku Alwirodi A road that destroys him who seeks water, by reason of its far extent. (O.)
halum-a i. q. naEaAla Come. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.)
It is intrans.; as in halum-a UilayonaA Come to us. And tran also; as in halum-a XuhadaMCa kumo Cause your witnesses to come; bring your witnesses. (Mṣb.)
halum-a jar-FA At thine ease: see 1 in art. jr.
1. ham-a He purposed, or intended, a thing. ham-N denotes more than UiraAdapN, and less than EazomN. (Kull, p. 382.)
laA maham-apa walaA makaAdapa: see art. kwd.
ham-a biAlX-aIoCi [He meditated, proposed to himself, purposed, or intended, to do the thing:] he desired to do the thing, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) without doing it; (Mṣb;) he endeavoured to do the thing. (Ṣ.)
ham-a biAlOamori He intended the affair. or purposed it; or he desired it. (Mgh.)
ham-a bihi fiI nafosihi [aor. _u {yahomumu}] He intended it, meant it, desired it. or determined upon it, in his mind. (TA.) See also a verse cited voce rutamN.
hm biAlbakaMCi [He was about, or ready, to weep; like OaraAda AlbukaMCa, and tahay-aOa lilbukaMCi q. v.]. (A, art. jhX, &c.)
ham-a bAls-uquwT [It threatened to fall], said of a wall. (Ṣ, in art. whI, &c.)
ham-ahu and Oaham-ahu↓ It disquieted him; (Mṣb;) caused him care, or anxiety.
laA yuhim-uhu Uil-aA baTonuhu [Nothing causes him care, or anxiety, but his belly]. (Ṣ in art. bTn.)
4. Oaham-atu It rendered him anxious; (MA;) disquieted him, and grieved him. (Mgh.) See EanaAhu.
7. Ainhm-a: see a verse cited in art. b, p. 144.

8. Aihotam-a biAlOamori He was grieved, and disquieted, by the affair, or case: (TA:) you say Aihotam-a lahu biOamorihi he was grieved for him by his affair, or case. (Ṣ.) [He was, or became, anxious, disquieted, or grieved, by it.]
He minded, or attended to, the affair: (MA:) undertook, or superintended, or managed, the affair. (Mṣb.) See EuniIa, in art. EnI.
Aihotam-a lahu He cared for, minded, or regarded, him, or it. (Ḥar, p. 94.)
Aihotam-a balada kacaA i. q. AiEotas-ahu. (TA in art. Es.)
hama for hamaA for OamaA before an oath: see the last.
ham-N and him-apN↓ Purpose, or intention; syn. Oaw-alu AlEazomi and Oaw-alu AlEaziymapi. (Mṣb.) See Ḥar, p. 345, and a verse cited voce Tal-aAE.
Also ↓the latter, Strong determination or resolution. (Mṣb.)
ham-N An object, or a thing intended or meant or desired or determined upon, in the mind. (Ḳ,* TA.) See an ex. voce Ham-N and sam-N: you say, ham-uhu kacaA His object is such a thing.

ham-N [Anxiety; or disquietude, or trouble, of mind; solicitude; care: or grief, or sorrow:] distress, or disquietude, affecting the heart or mind, by reason of some harm, or annoyance, that is expected to happen; differing from gam-N, which signifies “distress, or disquietude, affecting the heart or mind, by reason of what has happened:” or both, as some say, signify the same [namely distress, or disquietude, of mind]: the difference is asserted by ʼIyáḍ and others. (TA in art. gm.)
ham-uhu baTonuhu [His object of care, or of anxiety, is his belly]. (Ḳ in art. bTn.) And laA ham-a lahu Uil-aA baTonuhu [He has no object of care, or of anxiety, but his belly]. (TA in that art.)
ham-aka maA ham-aka means ham-aka maA EanaAka: and ham-aka also signifies AcAbk. (JK.) See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 880.
him-N A decrepit, old, and weak, or extremely aged. man. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
ham-apN: see him-apN.
him-apN [Ambition; particularly of a high kind;] a faculty firmly rooted in the soul, seeking high things, and fleeing from base things. (Ibn-Kemál, in TA.) See baEiydu, and ham-N.
him-apN [Mind; purpose; aspiration; desire; ambition; enterprise; emprise.]
humaAmN An aspiring king: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a magnanimous, i. e. courageous and liberal, chief. (Ḳ.)
hamohaAmN A wild bird of the crow kind: see SuradN.

haAmapN, pl. hawaAm-u, Any venomous creeping thing or reptile or the like, that may be killed; such as the scorpion, and the serpent: and ‡ a louse; (Mgh:) what has deadly venom; as the scorpion: (Az, Mṣb:) and sometimes, what is noxious: (Mṣb:) any reptile or the like, from the louse to the serpent; (AḤát, Mṣb:) but its application to the louse is tropical: (Mṣb:) any venomous or noxious reptile or the like; such as the scorpion, and the serpent: the like of serpents and scorpions; because they creep (tahim-u, i. e. tadib-). (JK.)

muhim-N A difficult, an arduous, a distressing, or an afflictive affair, or business: syn. OamorN XadiydN: (Ṣ:) and muhim-aAtN signifies Oumuwru XidaAdN, (JK,) affairs of difficulty: and, of importance.
baradN munoham-N [app. Dissolving hail-stones]. (Mughnee and Ḳ, in explanations of ka.) See a verse in explanation of bi used redundantly, p. 144.
hamodapN A trance: so rendered voce raqodapN.
hamarojalN A bulky she-camel. (IAạr, TA, voce XamarodalN.)
8. AihotimaAXN The intermingling, or interpenetrating. (KL.)
And the proceeding slowly. (KL.) See qarotana.
1. hamala, aor. _u {yahomulu}, inf. n. hamalAanN; and Ainohamala↓; It (water) overflowed, and poured forth. (Mgh.)

tuhomalu EalaI ruWuwsihaA waZahuwrihaA; so in a copy of the Ḳ, voce wasuwTN: in other copies of the Ḳ, tuHomalu or yuHomalu: if the first be correct, the meaning is probably Camels left without rein and without burden; and this is agreeable with the context.
4. Oahomala AlmaAXiyapa He sent [or left] the cattle to pasture [by themselves,] without a pastor, by night and by day. (Mṣb.)

Oahomalahu He left it, let it alone, or neglected it, intentionally or from forgetting: (Mṣb:) or he left it, or let it alone, expl. by xal-aI bayonahu wabayona nafosihi: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or he left it, or neglected it, and did not make use of it. (Ḳ.)
Oahomala Eabodahu (Ṣ, Ḳ, in art. sbE) He left his slave without work, or occupation: (PṢ:) he left him to himself, uncontrolled.
7. Ainohamalaka fiI AlOamori He exerted himself, strove, or laboured, in the affair, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and persisted, or persevered, in it. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

sense.hi: He obstinately persevered in vain or false affairs.

entry.sense: ham-aAlapN Applied to the eye or eyes, Flowing abundantly with tears: see a verse cited voce Ealafa.
muHomalN Having no government. (TA, art. on the particle fa.)
lafoZN muHomalN A word that has no grammatical government; contr. of EaAmilN. (IbrD.)

hanN and han-N A thing: and a penis: and the vulva of a woman: (KL:) or the former is pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of hanapN↓, which signifies a small, or little, thing: (MA:) or this last signifies a thing, (KL,) as does hanN: (Ḳ, KL:) [but the former meaning I have found to be very common, and I think it the more approvable. hanapN↓ may be rendered something, somewhat:] it denotes anything. (TA.)
hanapN: see hanN.
hinobirN A light, or an active, ass. (IAạr, in TA, voce yaEofuwrN.)
AlhanoEapu Two white stars, [g and c of Gemini,] between which is the space of the length of a whip, in the Milky Way; one of which is called Alzar-u, the other AlmayosaAnu.
The 6th Mansion of the Moon. (El-Ḳazweenee)

Or The three stars [l, f 1, and f 2,] in the face of Orion. (Idem, descr. of Orion.) [The former accord. to those who make nawoCN to signify the “auroral setting:” the latter accord. to those who make it to signify the “auroral rising:” accord. to those who make it to have the first of these two significations, the three stars in the face of Orion compose AlhaqoEapu, q. v.] See Alt-aHaAyiI, in art. HI.
Q. Q. 1. hayonama He concealed, or kept secret, a story; syn. Oasar-a. (A, art. jhr.)
hayoEuwEapN, originally hayowaEuwEapN: see XaAxa.
mahuwlN Terrible. (TA.)
naAru Almuhaw-ali: see naArN.
2. haw-ama He slept. (TA, voce naAma.)

haAmahN The head: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the part between the two edges of the head: or the middle, and main part, of the head, [see qaronN, and SadFI, in several places,] of anything: (TA:) or the upper part of the head, in which are the naASiyap and the quS-ah, which mean the fore part of the hair of the forehead; in it is the mfrq, which is the frq of the head, between the two sides, extending to the daAYarap. (AZ, TA.) See also two explanations voce jumojamapN.
haAmapN The crown, or top, of the head. See qamaHoduwapN, and AiEotajara.
haAmN meaning Headmen, or chiefs: see a verse cited in art. glSm.
banaAtu AlhaAmi The marrow of the brain. (TA.)
Oum-u AlhaAmi (Ḳ in art. dmg) app. i. q. Oum-u Alr-aOosi and Oum-u Ald-imaAgi: see Oum-N and dimAagN.

haAmapN An owl: a certain night-bird, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) that frequents the burial-places, of small size, (TA,) i. q. SadFI: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or i. q. buwmapN: (TA:) pl. [or coll. gen. n.] haAmN. (Ṣ.) See buwmN; and see also OaHar-a.

1. haAna, inf. n. hawaAnN and huwnN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and mahaAnapN, (Ḳ,) He, or it, was, or became, low, base, vile, abject, mean, paltry, contemptible, despicable, ignominious, inglorious, and weak; syn. cal-a, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Haqura, (Mṣb,) and DaEufa. (TA.)
haAna Ealayohi [It was of light estimation to him] It (a thing) was [easy and] light to him. (TA.)
haAna also, He, or it, was, or became, gentle, and easy. (Mṣb.)
2. haw-anahu Ealayohi He (God) made it easy and light to him. (Ḳ,* TA.)
haw-iniI AlOamora walAa taHozaniyI lahu [Make thou the case, or affair, light, or easy; i. e., regard it lightly; and do not grieve for it]. (TA, art. xfD.)
4. OahaAhahu, and AisotahaAna↓ bihi, and tahaAwana↓ bihi, He held him in light, or little, or mean, estimation, or in contempt; despised him; made light of him or it. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.)
OahaAnahu He lowered, or abased, him; debased him; rendered him abject, vile, mean, paltry, contemptible, despicable, or ignominious.
6. tahaAowana see 4.
10. Uisotahowana see 4.
hayonN and hay-inN↓ Easy: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and the latter of light estimation, paltry, despicable. (Ḳ,* TA.)
hay-inN: see hayonN.
Oahowanu in the sense of hay-inN: see Oakobaru. See also an ex. voce baSiyrapN; and another voce baEorN.
baEiyrN muhaAnN EalaI Oaholihi [A camel held in mean estimation by his owner]. (TA, art. dfE.)
1. hawaI bihi He made it to fall down: see an ex. in a verse of Ru-beh, cited voce riyAagN, in art. ryg.
See 4.
hawato Oucunuhu His ears heard a confused, or humming, or singing, sound. (Ḳ.)
hawato Oum-uhu is used to express wonder; like as when one says, qaAtalahu Qll-ehu maA OasomaEahu. (IB, in TA, art. Am.)

4. OahowaI UilaI AlX-aIoCi biyadihi He extended, or stretched forth, his arm, or hand, to the thing to take it; it being near: if it be distant, you say, hawaI↓ Uilayohi, without A. (Mṣb.) And OahowaI UilI sayofihi He reached his sword; took it with his hand, or with his extended hand; or took hold of it. (Mṣb.) And Oahowayotu biAlX-aIoCi [in my copy of the Mṣb, erroneously, UilaI AlX-aIoCi] I made a sign with the thing. (Aṣ, Ṣ.)
5. tahaw-aha: see MhapN, in art. Awh.
7. AinohawaI: see AinogawaI, in art. gw.
haAho and haAhu: see Mhi, in art. Awh.

AlhawaI Love, and attachment: then, inclination of the soul, or mind, to a thing: then, blameable inclination; as when one says, Ait-abaEa hawaAhu [He followed his evil inclination]; and huwa mino Oaholi AlOahowaMCi [see below]. (Mṣb.) See also Hub-N.

hawFI Also signifies Beloved [or an object of love]. (Ḳ, Ḥam, p. 546.) [Being originally an inf. n., it may be used alike as sing. and pl. See an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph {1} of art. zyn: and see an ex. voce XakolN.]

AlhawaI The inclination of the soul to that in which the animal appetites take delight, without any lawful invitation thereto; (KT;) [natural desire:] love, and desire; generally, such as is not praiseworthy: (Mgh:) I render it, love, or desirous love.

[Its pl.] OahowaMCN also signifies Opinions declining, or swerving, from the right way, or from the truth. (Bḍ, ii. 114.) [Hence,] Oaholu AlOahowaMCi [The people of erroneous opinions]. (T, in art. smE;, &c.)
UijoEali AlOamora huw-apF waAHidapN Make thou the affair, or case, [uniform, or] one uniform thing. (Fr in TA, in art. bOj.)
hawaMCN A vacancy; a vacuity; a vacant, or an empty, space. (Mgh.)
A vacant, or an empty, thing. (Mṣb.)
hawiI-N and huwiI-N: see 4, (last sentence), in art. slm.
haAwanN, said to be thus, with fet-ḥ to the w, originally haAwuwnN, [A mortar;] the thing in which one pounds, or bruises: pl. hawaAwiynu. (Mṣb.)
haAwiyapN An abyss; a depth, or deep place, of which the bottom cannot be reached. (JK, TA.)
mahowaI [The cavity of the well]. (Ḳ, voce UizaMCN.)
See mahowaApN.
mahowaApN: see huw-apN.
The space between two mountains; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and the like; as also mahowFI↓: (Ṣ:) a pit, or hollow, dug, or excavated. (Mṣb.)
muhay-aON i. q. zumaAwarodN. (MF, art. wrd.)
5. tahay-afa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) said of a man, (Ṣ,) is from Alhayofu [the hot south-west wind], like tasat-aI from AlXit-aMCu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See an ex. voce maSoquwlN.
Alhayofu: respecting the wind thus called, see nakobaACu.
riyHN mihoyAafN [A very thirsty wind]. (TA, voce nakobAaCu.)
hayoqapN A female ostrich. (A, art. zmr.)
7. AinohaAla It (sand, &c.) poured down. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Ainohadama AljidaAru waMnohaAla [The wall fell in ruins, or to pieces, or became a ruin, and broke, or crumbled down]. (Ḳ in art. qyD.) So rendered voce AinoqaADa, art. fyD.
hayolN inf. n. of haAla: see HavaA.
hayolN and haAYilN↓ Sand that will not remain steady in its place, but falls down. (JK.)
hayuwluI and hay-uwlaI: wrongly mentioned in art. hwl. See maAd-apN.
mahiylN: see kaviybN.
2. hay-amahu: see huyuwmN.
hayaAmN: see an ex. in a verse of Lebeed, voce OaSolN.
huyaAmN: see hub-N.

huyuwmN [The being bewildered, or distracted, by amorous desire;] the pursuing a heedless, or an inconsiderate course, or going at random, heedlessly, or without consideration, or certain aim, by reason of amorous desire: and tahoyaAmN the [being so, or] doing so, much. (TA.) You say, of love [or amorous desire], hay-amahu↓, inf. n. tahoyiymN. (TA.)
An affection like insanity arising from amorous desire: (JK:) bewilderment, or distraction, by amorous desire. (KL.)
hayomaAnu A man loving intensely, or very passionately or fondly: (TA:) and so applied to a heart: see XaniqN.
hayomaAnu A thirsty camel: fem. hayomaI: pl. hiymN. (Jel, lvi. 55.)
mahoyuwmN: see voce qat-a.

1. haAna lahu, aor. yahiynu, He treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; syn. daAraAhu. (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, in TA, art. En; but only the imp., hino lahu, is there mentioned, said to be with kesr.) See Eaz-a, near the end, p. 2031, and the distinction there made between hino and huno.
hiyha and hiyhi and hiyhK: see Uiyha and Ayhi and UiyhK

hayohaAta kacaA Far, or far from being believed or from the truth, is such a thing; as also hayohaAta likacaA: or the latter means remoteness, or remoteness from being believed or from the truth, is to be attributed to such a thing: hayohaAta followed by li means baEuda, (Jel, in xxiii. 38,) or baEuda Alt-aSodiyqu or AlS-iH-apu: (Bḍ, ibid:) or AlbuEodu: (Bḍ, ibid, TA:) and without li after it, it denotes the pronouncing [a thing] remote. (TA.) See OayohaAta.

hayohaAt denotes one's deeming a thing remote, or improbable, and despairing of it; and means baEuda jid-FA [Very far,, &c.], or mA OaboEada [How far,, &c.]; implying more than baEuda though we render it by this word. (Kull, p. 382.)
Aibonu haI-K and Abn hay-aAna The low, ignoble, mean, contemptible, man. (T in art. bnI.)
